metadata.sermon_start_end: ABOUT EIGHT years ago, I was having lunch in New York City with a person well enough known and sufficiently sophisticated to be a bit intimidating. We had recently been introduced and were meeting to discuss some points raised in his latest book. After some discussion of those [...] The glory of the Lord shall be revealed, and all flesh shall see it together, for the mouth of the Lord has spoken it. AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The preacher explicitly rejects the discipline of the specific pericope, opting instead for a 'canonical' overview of fifteen chapters. This violates Dekker's rule that a sermon is not about 'the Bible as a whole' or a 'biblical idea'. By treating Isaiah 40-55 as a monolith, the preacher resorts to generalities about God's sovereignty rather than the unique, unrepeatable word of a specific text.
quotes: Actually, it would be more accurate to say that our text tonight is the entire fifteen chapters that make up what we call Deutero-Isaiah
It’s all there in those fifteen chapters: creation, fall, judgment, kingdom, redemption, crucifixion, new creation — all of it
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Restrict the focus to Isaiah 43:10-11. Identify what this specific text says about 'witnessing' that is distinct from the general theme of sovereignty in the rest of the corpus.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher demonstrates awareness of the historical context (exile in Babylon, imperial idols). However, the exegesis remains at the level of 'religious history' rather than a deep linguistic or theological 'exposition' of the Hebrew text itself. It functions more as a thematic backdrop.
quotes: He is living in a civilization that is utterly foreign in every way. He is a member of a humiliated, exiled population
One of the most striking aspects of Isaiah’s prophecy is the mocking of the gods and idols of Babylon.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Engage with the specific Hebrew terminology of 'witness' (ed) and 'servant' (ebed) to show how these roles functioned legally or cultically in the original context.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding the state of the American church and politics (Iraq war, Bush administration), which Dekker would appreciate. However, it often slips into 'general truths' about the 'mainlines' versus 'the right' rather than a specific spiritual application for the individual hearer's life before God.
quotes: I believe that the American church is suffering acutely from an unwillingness of the mainlines and the Christian right to talk to each other
The evangelical churches were and are hand-in-glove with the Bush administration for the most part.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond ecclesiastical politics to the 'zeitgeist' as it affects the spiritual life of the individual: how does the 'idolatry' of modern sophisticated life specifically hinder the hearer from seeing God as the 'subject'?

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The text is structured more as a lecture or 'teaching' (as the author admits) than a sermon. Large blocks of anecdotal reflection on the state of the church are followed by blocks of Scripture reading. The 'present of revelation' where the text and hearer converge is frequently interrupted by the preacher's personal travelogue.
quotes: It is more a teaching than a sermon, but it has some sermonic qualities.
I have probably heard more sermons by more clergy in more churches in more denominations than any other preacher I have ever met.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Reduce the autobiographical 'I' and the meta-commentary on preaching. Allow the text's own movement to 'expound' the hearer directly.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon is strong on 'misery' (the furnace of affliction, the silence of God) and 'redemption' (God as the acting subject). It avoids a shallow Christocentrism by focusing on the Trinitarian 'living God'. The psychological reality of doubt is taken seriously.
quotes: God is active even when hidden, even when seemingly absent. ‘I have tried you in the furnace of affliction’
The subject in so much of our preaching is ourselves... The subject isn’t God.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Develop the 'gratitude' aspect more concretely. How does being a 'witness' translate into a life of specific, Spirit-awakened gratitude?

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The preacher touches on the 'perilous state of affairs' and the 'demonization' of others, but the ultimate seriousness of being 'lost' (temporal or eternal) is muted. The choice is presented more as a theological/ecclesiastical impasse than a life-and-death journey.
quotes: This fragmentation is a perilous state of affairs, it seems to me.
The question is whether God is ‘living and active’
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the consequence of *not* acknowledging God as the subject. What is the 'destruction' that awaits a church or a person who remains their own subject?

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned at the beginning and end, but he is not the 'telos' of the exposition. The preacher relies on a general 'God-centeredness'. While Dekker warns against 'too Christocentric' preaching, he insists Christ cannot be silenced and must be the goal. Here, Christ feels like a liturgical addition rather than the internal necessity of the Isaiah text.
quotes: the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ confirm his Word in you all.
It’s all there in those fifteen chapters: ... crucifixion, new creation
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Show how the 'servant' in Isaiah specifically finds its telos in Christ, making grace the 'deepest of our life' rather than just a theological concept of 'God as subject'.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 21 minutes, the sermon meets Dekker's minimum requirement for 'breadth'. It attempts a high degree of theological depth, though this is sometimes diluted by the broadness of the chosen text (15 chapters).
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Trade the breadth of the 15-chapter overview for the depth of a single pericope to achieve the 'specific' depth Dekker demands.

overall_assessment.summary: The text functions more as a homiletic essay or a 'clergy-to-clergy' lecture than a sermon. It fails Dekker's primary formal requirement by refusing to ground itself in a specific, limited Bible passage, opting instead for a thematic survey. While it correctly identifies the 'misery' of a God-less pulpit and asserts the sovereignty of God (God as Subject), it lacks the interwoven urgency of a proclamatory word.
strengths: Strong diagnosis of the 'zeitgeist' within the church where man has become the subject.
Adequate length and sober, theological tone.
Serious engagement with the 'hiddenness' of God and human suffering.
weaknesses: Lack of focus on a specific pericope leads to generalities.
Excessive autobiographical content ('I have heard more sermons...') distracts from the Word.
Christ is not the clear telos of the message, appearing only in the periphery.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an insightful theological speech, but it is not a 'sermon' in the strict Dekkerian sense. It lacks the 'recreating' of a specific Bible passage into a current, proclamatory word, and the preacher's persona occupies too much space that belongs to the Text.
